On the other hand, if a child is exposed to negative reinforcement, they may develop a negative self-image and low self-esteem, which can lead to poor academic performance and other issues. \n\nFurthermore, a child's formative years are the perfect time to instill values and beliefs. This is because a child is more likely to accept and internalize these values without question, as they are still forming their own beliefs and opinions. This can lead to a person who is more likely to make better decisions in the future, as they have a foundation of values to draw from. \n\nIn conclusion, a person's childhood years are the most important years of their life, as this is when a person's character, values, and beliefs are formed, as well as their sense of self-worth and identity. This is why it is essential to provide a safe and supportive environment for children during this period, so that they can reach their full potential.", "esl_essay": "I strongly agree with the statement that a person's childhood years (time from birth to twelve years old) are the most important years in a person's life. For example, research has shown that children who are exposed to positive experiences, such as having loving and supportive parents, can develop resilience and a strong sense of self-esteem that can help them succeed in life. On the other hand, children who are exposed to negative experiences, such as abuse or neglect, can have lasting psychological and emotional scars that can impede their future success. \n\nFurthermore, a person's childhood years are also the time when they are most open to learning and absorbing information. Additionally, luck can be fleeting and unpredictable, while hard work is a consistent and reliable way to achieve success."}

This taught me to be more mindful of my spending and to appreciate the value of a dollar. I also had to reach out to family and friends for help, which made me more appreciative of the support system around me. \n\nMoreover, difficult times can help us develop a better perspective on what is important in life. When I was unemployed, I realized that material possessions are not as important as I thought they were. I stopped worrying about buying the latest gadgets and started focusing on things that really mattered, like spending time with family and friends. I also started to focus on activities that made me feel fulfilled, like reading and writing. \n\nIn conclusion, difficult times can be a blessing in disguise, as they can teach us invaluable lessons and help us develop a better perspective on life.", "esl_essay": "I agree with the statement that most experiences in our lives that initially seem difficult eventually become valuable lessons for the future. Life is full of challenges and obstacles that can be difficult to overcome at the time, but when we look back on them later, we can often see that they were necessary to help us grow and develop as a person. For example, when I was younger, I found math to be a difficult subject and I struggled to understand it. However, as I have gotten older, I have been able to look back and recognize that those struggles I had with math were actually valuable lessons that have helped me to develop my problem-solving and logical thinking skills. \n\nIn addition, I have also had experiences that were difficult at the time but that I have since been able to look back on and realize were not as important or significant as I had thought. Exercise can help students focus better in class, improve their mood, and even increase their IQ. Exercise can also help reduce stress and anxiety, which can be a major distraction in the classroom.\n\nIn conclusion, physical exercise should be a required part of every school day. Finally, physical activity can help to foster teamwork and cooperation, as well as provide an outlet for students to release their energy and burn off excess energy and restlessness. \n\nOn the other hand, there are those who argue that all children should focus on book work during the school day. They are able to work more efficiently and effectively when they are at their peak, and they are able to finish their tasks quicker. \n\nIn conclusion, I believe that waking up early in the morning and starting the day's work is the best way to maximize productivity and efficiency. I am able to plan ahead, stay focused, and make the most of my time. I find that this approach helps me stay ahead of the game and reach my goals."}

{"index": 99, "sae_prompt": "Some people think that the automobile has improved modern life. Others think that the automobile has caused serious problems. What is your opinion? Other believes that the automobile has caused serious problems. What is you opinion? Use specifics reason and examples for support your answer.", "sae_essay": "The automobile has had a profound impact on modern life, both positive and negative. On the one hand, the automobile has made it easier for people to travel and explore, allowing us to access places we wouldn't have been able to before. It has also improved the quality of life by reducing the amount of time spent on manual labor and providing more leisure time. On the other hand, the automobile has caused a number of problems, such as air pollution, traffic congestion, and a decrease in physical activity. \n\nThe most obvious negative impact of the automobile is air pollution. Cars and other vehicles emit gases and particles into the atmosphere that are harmful to human health and the environment. This air pollution has been linked to respiratory diseases, such as asthma, and has been shown to reduce crop yields and damage ecosystems. \n\nTraffic congestion is another issue caused by the automobile. As the number of cars on the road increases, so does the amount of time spent in traffic. This leads to increased stress, wasted time, and fuel costs. It also contributes to air pollution, as vehicles sit idling in traffic. \n\nFinally, the automobile has led to a decrease in physical activity. With the ability to quickly and easily travel to any destination, people are less inclined to walk or bike to their destinations. This has led to a decrease in physical fitness and an increase in health problems related to inactivity. \n\nIn conclusion, the automobile has both positive and negative impacts on modern life. While it has improved our ability to travel and explore, it has also caused air pollution, traffic congestion, and a decrease in physical activity. It is important to be aware of these impacts and take steps to reduce their effects.", "aae_essay": "Cars have certainly changed life in many ways for the better. They have made it easier for people to travel long distances quickly and conveniently, which has opened up new opportunities for work, leisure, and social activities. Cars have also improved access to healthcare, education, and other essential services. On the other hand, cars have also brought some negative impacts, such as air pollution, traffic congestion, and safety risks. \n\nFor example, air pollution has become a major issue in many cities due to the large number of cars on the road. Cars are a major source of air pollution, as they emit gases such as carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxides, and particulate matter. This can lead to respiratory illnesses, such as asthma, and other health problems. \n\nIn addition, cars have caused traffic congestion in many cities, making it difficult for people to get around. This can lead to increased stress levels, as people spend more time in their cars and less time doing other activities. \n\nFinally, cars have also made people more vulnerable to accidents. With the speed and power of cars, a crash can have serious consequences, both physically and mentally. \n\nOverall, cars have had both positive and negative impacts on life today. It is important to be aware of the risks associated with cars and to take necessary precautions to protect ourselves and others.", "esl_essay": "The automobile has had a profound impact on modern life, both positive and negative. On the one hand, the automobile has made it easier for people to travel and explore the world, allowing for more efficient and faster transportation than ever before. It has also improved access to goods and services, as people can now access stores and markets from anywhere. Additionally, the automobile has enabled people to work from home, as many jobs can now be done from the comfort of a car. \n\nOn the other hand, the automobile has caused a number of problems. It has led to increased air and noise pollution, as well as traffic congestion in many cities. It has also led to a decrease in physical activity, as people are less likely to walk or bike places due to the availability of cars. Furthermore, the automobile has caused a decrease in public transportation, as people prefer to drive their own cars instead. \n\nOverall, the automobile has both improved and worsened modern life. It has enabled people to explore and access more, but has also caused air and noise pollution, traffic congestion, and a decrease in physical activity. It is up to governments and individuals to find ways to reduce the negative impacts of the automobile and make sure it continues to improve life, not worsen it."}

Use specific reason and example for support your opinion.", "sae_essay": "Preserving old, historic buildings is essential to a city's identity and culture, and should be a priority for city planners. These buildings are often architectural gems that have been around for decades or even centuries, and they provide a sense of place and history to a city. \n\nIn addition, preserving old buildings can help to maintain the character of a city and prevent urban sprawl. Furthermore, preserving old buildings can help to reduce the cost of construction, as cities do not need to pay for the materials or labor to build new structures. \n\nIn conclusion, preserving old, historic buildings is essential to a city's identity and culture, and should be a priority for city planners. Older buildings provide a sense of place and history, help to maintain the character of a city, and can be more sustainable and cost-effective than new buildings.", "aae_essay": "In recent years, there has been a debate over whether cities should preserve their old, historic buildings or tear them down and replace them with new, modern structures. On the other hand, modern buildings can bring more economic growth and provide more efficient uses of space. \n\nFor example, in the city of London, England, the city council is currently considering whether to preserve the iconic Bankside Power Station or to replace it with a new, modern development. The power station has been a landmark in the city since it was built in 1947, but it has become outdated and is in need of costly repairs. The new development would bring more jobs and economic growth to the area, as well as provide more efficient uses of the land. \n\nIn conclusion, while preserving old buildings can be beneficial for maintaining a city's identity and heritage, modern buildings can bring more economic growth and more efficient uses of space. This will help to ensure that students are engaged and motivated, which in turn leads to better learning outcomes. \n\nFor example, in my experience as a teacher, I have found that when I ask my students what topics they would like to learn about, they are more likely to be engaged in the lesson and to retain the information longer. Additionally, when I offer them the opportunity to pursue topics that interest them, they are more likely to be motivated and to work harder. This has been especially true for students who are reluctant learners. \n\nOn the other hand, there may be some circumstances where offering students what they want could be detrimental to their learning. For example, if students are not given structure and guidance, they may be able to pursue topics that are not as beneficial to their learning. Additionally, if the curriculum is too tailored to the individual student, it may be difficult to ensure that all students are receiving the same quality of education. \n\nOverall, I believe that finding out what students want and then offering it to them is a beneficial approach to curriculum design. By taking the time to understand the interests of the students, educators can create a curriculum that is tailored to their individual needs and interests, which in turn leads to better learning outcomes."}

Despite being shot by the Taliban for advocating for girls\u2019 education, she has continued to fight for her beliefs and has become a leading voice for peace and justice. Similarly, the efforts of activists like Martin Luther King Jr. and Rosa Parks to fight for civil rights are still seen as heroic today. \n\nMoreover, heroism can also be found in everyday acts of kindness. People who volunteer their time to help those in need, donate to charities, or stand up for what they believe in are all examples of heroic behavior. \n\nIn conclusion, while the definition of heroism has changed over time, there are still people who have made significant contributions to society and embody the qualities of heroism.", "aae_essay": "The concept of a hero has changed drastically over the years. In the past, a hero was someone who was admired for their courage, strength, and self-sacrifice. Today, however, the word \u201chero\u201d is often used to describe celebrities and public figures who have achieved success in their field. People no longer look to these individuals for courage and self-sacrifice, but instead for entertainment and inspiration. This shift in perception has made it difficult to define who is and is not a hero.\n\nIn the past, heroes were people who put themselves in harm\u2019s way to help others. They were willing to risk their own safety to save someone else\u2019s life. Today, heroes are often people who have achieved success in their field, such as athletes, entertainers, and politicians. While these individuals have certainly worked hard to achieve their success, it is difficult to say that they have put themselves in harm\u2019s way to help others.\n\nAnother way to define a hero is by their actions in the face of adversity. In the past, heroes were people who faced difficult challenges and overcame them. Today, heroes are often people who have achieved success despite the odds. For example, a person who starts a business from the ground up and makes it successful is seen as a hero, even though they faced many challenges along the way.\n\nThe concept of a hero has changed drastically over the years, and it is difficult to define who is and is not a hero. A successful leader must be able to recognize the value of working together with others in order to achieve a goal. A leader must be able to understand the strengths and weaknesses of their team and be able to leverage them to reach the desired outcome. A leader must also be able to recognize when to take the lead and when to follow, and be able to do so in a way that encourages collaboration and respect. \n\nFor example, when leading a team of engineers, a successful leader must be able to recognize the individual strengths of each engineer and be able to assign tasks accordingly. The leader must also be able to provide guidance and feedback to ensure that the team is working together towards a common goal. Additionally, the leader must be able to recognize when to take the lead on a project and when to follow the lead of another engineer. This requires a leader to be able to understand the strengths and weaknesses of their team and be able to leverage them to reach the desired outcome. \n\nIn conclusion, a successful leader must be both competitive and cooperative. They must be able to recognize the strengths and weaknesses of their team and be able to leverage them to reach the desired outcome. They must also be able to recognize when to take the lead and when to follow, and do so in a way that encourages collaboration and respect."}

This can be done by providing resources such as career counseling, courses, and connections to employers. With the right resources, students can make informed decisions about their studies and be better prepared for the job market."}

This is especially important in college, where students should be striving to gain knowledge and skills that will help them pursue their dreams. On the other hand, it is also important to consider the job market. This is especially important for students who are looking to enter the job market after college. \nIn conclusion, I believe that students should choose their field of study based on their passion and skills, but also consider the job market when making their decision. This will help them to pursue their dreams while also being realistic about the job opportunities available.", "esl_essay": "I believe that college students should consider both their own talents and interests, as well as the job availability in a field, when choosing a field of study. Students should research the job market and the potential for employment in their chosen field before making a final decision. This will help them to make an informed decision that will set them up for success in their future career."}

{"index": 336, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in an article written by Dr. Karp, an anthropologist.\n\"Twenty years ago, Dr. Field, a noted anthropologist, visited the island of Tertia and concluded from his observations that children in Tertia were reared by an entire village rather than by their own biological parents. However, my recent interviews with children living in the group of islands that includes Tertia show that these children spend much more time talking about their biological parents than about other adults in the village. This research of mine proves that Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture is invalid and thus that the observation-centered approach to studying cultures is invalid as well. The interview-centered method that my team of graduate students is currently using in Tertia will establish a much more accurate understanding of child-rearing traditions there and in other island cultures.\"\nWrite a response in which you examine the stated and/or unstated assumptions of the argument. Be sure to explain how the argument depends on these assumptions and what the implications are for the argument if the assumptions prove unwarranted.", "aae_prompt": "Check it, this what Dr. Karp, who be an anthropologist, had to say in one article:\n\"Like, twenty years back, Dr. Field, who errybody know as a big-time anthropologist, hit up Tertia island and from what he peeped, he figured them kids in Tertia was gettin' raised by the whole hood instead of they own folks. But yo, I been choppin' it up with the youngins on the islands 'round Tertia and they be yappin' way more 'bout they mommas and poppas than 'bout other grown folks in the village. The way me and my grad students gettin' down with interviews in Tertia right now gon' lay down the real deal 'bout how they do that child-rearin' thing there and in other island spots.\"\n\nAight, so you gotta break down the assumptions Dr. Karp makin' in his argument. Make sure you get into how the whole thing is leanin' on these assumptions and what it mean for his talk if these assumptions ain't holdin' water.", "esl_prompt": "The following appeared in an article written by Dr. Karp, an anthropologist.\n\"Twenty year ago, Dr. Field, a noted anthropologist, visited the island of Tertia and concluded from his observation that children in Tertia was reared by an entire village rather than by their own biological parents. However, my recent interview with children living in the group of islands that includes Tertia shows that these children spends much more time talking about their biological parents than about other adults in the village. This research of mine prove that Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture is not valid and thus that the observation-centered approach to studying cultures is not valid as well. The interview-centered method that my team of graduate students is currently using in Tertia will establish a much more accurate understanding of child-rearing traditions there and in other island cultures.\"\nWrite a response in which you examine the stated and/or unstated assumptions of the argument. Be sure to explain how the argument depends on these assumptions and what the implications are for the argument if the assumptions prove unwarranted.", "sae_essay": "The argument presented depends on the assumption that the observation-centered approach to studying cultures is invalid and that the interview-centered method is a more accurate way of understanding child-rearing traditions in Tertia and other island cultures. This assumption is based on the premise that the interview-centered method allows for a more in-depth understanding of the culture, as it allows for direct inquiry into the beliefs and experiences of the people being studied. This method also allows for a more personal connection to be formed between the interviewer and the interviewee, which can lead to more honest and accurate answers. \n\nHowever, this argument does not take into account the potential biases that can be introduced by the interviewer, or the fact that the interviewee may feel uncomfortable answering personal questions. Additionally, the interview-centered method does not provide the same level of objectivity as the observation-centered approach, which can lead to a limited understanding of the culture being studied. \n\nOverall, the argument presented depends on the assumption that the interview-centered method is a more accurate way of understanding child-rearing traditions in Tertia and other island cultures, which has not been proven and may not be the case.", "aae_essay": "Dr. Karp's argument is based on the assumption that the children in Tertia are being raised by the entire village instead of their own parents. This assumption is questionable as I have been talking to the children on the islands around Tertia and they have been telling me that they are being raised by their parents, not the village. Furthermore, my research shows that Dr. Field's idea that the children in Tertia are being raised by the village is not accurate. This means that the way Dr. Karp is going about studying the culture of Tertia is not effective and he needs to rethink his approach.", "esl_essay": "The argument presented by Dr. Karp depends on several assumptions which, if untrue, would render the argument invalid. The first assumption is that the children of Tertia do not spend time talking about their biological parents, when in fact this may not be the case. The second assumption is that the observation-centered approach to studying cultures is not valid, when in fact this approach has been used successfully in many anthropological studies. The third assumption is that the interview-centered method used by Dr. Karp and his team of graduate students will provide a more accurate understanding of child-rearing traditions in Tertia and other island cultures. If the interviews do not probe deeply enough or ask the right questions, then the conclusions drawn from them may be invalid. \n\nThe implications of these assumptions being false are that Dr. Karp's argument is not valid and that the observation-centered approach to studying cultures should not be discounted. If the observation-centered approach is valid, then Dr. Karp's argument is weakened as it relies on the assumption that the children of Tertia do not talk about their biological parents, which may not be the case. Additionally, if the interview-centered method is not reliable, then Dr. Karp's argument is weakened as it relies on the assumption that the interview-centered method will provide a more accurate understanding of child-rearing traditions in Tertia and other island cultures."}
{"index": 337, "sae_prompt": "A recently issued twenty-year study on headaches suffered by the residents of Mentia investigated the possible therapeutic effect of consuming salicylates. \nSalicylates are members of the same chemical family as aspirin, a medicine used to treat headaches. Although many foods are naturally rich in salicylates, food-processing companies also add salicylates to foods as preservatives. The twenty-year study found a correlation between the rise in the commercial use of salicylates and a steady decline in the average number of headaches reported by study participants. At the time when the study concluded, food-processing companies had just discovered that salicylates can also be used as flavor additives for foods, and, as a result, many companies plan to do so. Based on these study results, some health experts predict that residents of Mentia will suffer even fewer headaches in the future.\nWrite a response in which you discuss what questions would need to be answered in order to decide whether the prediction and the argument on which it is based are reasonable. Thus the number of students enrolled in our public schools will soon decrease dramatically, and we can safely reduce the funds budgeted for education during the next decade. At the same time, we can reduce funding for athletic playing fields and other recreational facilities. As a result, we will have sufficient money to fund city facilities and programs used primarily by adults, since we can expect the adult population of the city to increase.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.\n\nESL English:\n\nThe following appeared as a recommendation by a committee planning a ten-year budget for the city of Calatrava.\n\"The birthrate in our city is declining: in fact, last year birthrate was only one-half that of five years before. So the number of students enrolled in our public schools will soon decrease a lot, and we can safe reduce the funds budgeted for education during the next decade. At the same time, we can reduce funding for athletic playing fields and other recreational facilities. As a result, we will have enough money to fund city facilities and programs used mainly by adults, since we can expect the adult population of the city to increase.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is need to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "sae_essay": "The argument presented is that the city of Calatrava can reduce funding for education and recreational facilities because the birthrate in the city is declining and the adult population will increase. To evaluate this argument, evidence should be presented that shows the current birthrate and the projected birthrate in the next ten years. Additionally, evidence should be presented that shows the current and projected adult population of the city. This would allow the argument to be evaluated based on the actual data and not just assumptions. \n\nIf the birthrate is indeed declining and the adult population is projected to increase, then the argument could be strengthened. This would mean that the city can reallocate funds from education and recreational facilities to other areas, as the adult population will be able to support these other areas. However, if the birthrate is not declining and the adult population is not projected to increase, then the argument would be weakened, as there would not be enough adults to support the other areas.", "aae_essay": "In order to evaluate the accuracy of the committee's proposed budget plan, it is important to consider both the short-term and long-term implications of the proposed cuts. \n\nIn the short-term, the proposed cuts to education and recreational programs could have a significant impact on the community. Fewer resources for education could lead to lower test scores and a decrease in educational opportunities for children in the area. Additionally, fewer recreational programs could lead to an increase in juvenile delinquency and a decrease in community engagement. \n\nIn the long-term, the proposed cuts could have a devastating effect on the community. Fewer resources for education could lead to a decrease in the number of skilled workers available in the area, which could result in a decrease in economic growth. Additionally, fewer recreational programs could lead to an increase in health issues such as obesity and depression due to lack of physical activity and mental health issues due to lack of social interaction. \n\nOverall, the proposed budget plan should be carefully evaluated to ensure that the short-term and long-term implications are taken into account.", "esl_essay": "The argument presented is that the declining birthrate in the city of Calatrava will lead to a decrease in the number of students enrolled in public schools, and that this decrease can be used to reduce funds allocated for education. This argument is based on the assumption that the adult population of the city will increase in the next ten years, which has not been proven. Evidence that the adult population is indeed increasing would strengthen the argument, while evidence to the contrary would weaken it."}
{"index": 344, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a letter to the editor of Parson City's local newspaper.\n\"In our region of Trillura, the majority of money spent on the schools that most students attend \u2014 the city-run public schools \u2014 comes from taxes that each city government collects. {"index": 349, "sae_prompt": "The following report appeared in the newsletter of the West Meria Public Health Council.\n\"An innovative treatment has come to our attention that promises to significantly reduce absenteeism in our schools and workplaces. {"index": 354, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a health newsletter.\n\"A ten-year nationwide study of the effectiveness of wearing a helmet while bicycling indicates that ten years ago, approximately 35 percent of all bicyclists reported wearing helmets, whereas today that number is nearly 80 percent. These results demonstrate that bicyclists feel safer because they are wearing helmets, and they take more risks as a result. Thus, to reduce the number of serious injuries from bicycle accidents, the government should concentrate more on educating people about bicycle safety and less on encouraging or requiring bicyclists to wear helmets.\"\nWrite a response in which you examine the stated and/or unstated assumptions of the argument. {"index": 355, "sae_prompt": "The following is a letter to the head of the tourism bureau on the island of Tria.\n\"Erosion of beach sand along the shores of Tria Island is a serious threat to our island and our tourist industry. In order to stop the erosion, we should charge people for using the beaches. Although this solution may annoy a few tourists in the short term, it will raise money for replenishing the sand. Replenishing the sand, as was done to protect buildings on the nearby island of Batia, will help protect buildings along our shores, thereby reducing these buildings' risk of additional damage from severe storms. And since beaches and buildings in the area will be preserved, Tria's tourist industry will improve over the long term.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "aae_prompt": "Check it, dis a letter to da head of da tourism bureau on Tria Island.\n\n\"Da way da beach sand be washin' away on Tria Island's shores is a big problem for our spot and da folks comin' to chill here. In contrast, over the past three years, enrollment at Humana University has not grown and the cost for maintaining buildings has gone up. Thus, to increase enrollment and solve the problem of budget deficits at Humana University, we should to initiate and actively promote online degree programs like those at Omni.\"\nWrite a response in which you examine the stated and/or unstated assumptions of the argument. It also assumes that Humana University has failed to keep up with this trend and has experienced budget deficits as a result. The argument further assumes that initiating and actively promoting online degree programs at Humana University will increase enrollment and solve the budget deficits.\n\nThe argument depends on the assumption that the increase in online degree programs at Omni University is unique and has not been replicated at other universities. If this assumption is not true, then the argument does not hold and other universities may not have experienced the same success with online degree programs as Omni. Additionally, the argument assumes that Humana University has not been able to keep up with the trend of online degree programs, which may not be true. If Humana University has been actively pursuing online degree programs and they have simply not been successful, then the argument does not hold.\n\nThe implications of the argument are that if online degree programs at Omni University have been successful, then Humana University should initiate and actively promote online degree programs in order to increase enrollment and solve budget deficits. If the argument is not true, then the implications of the argument are that Humana University should continue to pursue other methods of increasing enrollment and reducing budget deficits.", "aae_essay": "The memo from the big boss at Humana University suggests that in order to increase enrollment and handle their money troubles, they need to follow the example of Omni University and offer online degree programs. Other methods should be explored and evaluated before making a decision.", "esl_essay": "The argument presented assumes that the increase in online degree programs at Omni University has led to an increase in enrollment and a decrease in expenditures for dormitory and classroom space. {"index": 362, "sae_prompt": "An ancient, traditional remedy for insomnia \u2014 the scent of lavender flowers \u2014 has now been proved effective. For example, it is possible that the lavender-scented pillows could have been a placebo effect, where the volunteers believed they were receiving the lavender treatment and it was this belief that caused them to sleep better. {"index": 368, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a memo from the vice president of marketing at Dura-Sock, Inc.\n\"A recent study of our customers suggests that our company is wasting the money it spends on its patented Endure manufacturing process, which ensures that our socks are strong enough to last for two years. Furthermore, our customers surveyed in our largest market, northeastern United States cities, say that they most value Dura-Socks' stylish appearance and availability in many colors. These findings suggest that we can increase our profits by discontinuing use of the Endure manufacturing process.\"\nWrite a response in which you examine the stated and/or unstated assumptions of the argument. Second, it assumes that the Endure process is the primary factor in Dura-Socks' popularity, when in fact other features such as style and availability in many colors may be equally or more important. Finally, it assumes that Dura-Socks' customers in the northeastern United States are the company's primary market, when in fact the company may have customers in other regions or countries who value the Endure process and its durability. If these assumptions prove unwarranted, then the argument that the company can increase its profits by discontinuing the Endure process is based on a false premise and should not be followed.", "aae_essay": "The argument presented in the memo suggests that Dura-Sock, Inc. could potentially increase their profits by eliminating their patented Endure manufacturing process. The argument is based on the premise that their customers are still purchasing new socks every three months, despite the fact that the Endure process is supposed to make the socks last two years. Additionally, the memo mentions that the customers in the northeastern cities in the US, which is Dura-Sock's biggest market, are particularly fond of the socks' style and colors. \n\nThe argument presented is that by eliminating the Endure process, Dura-Sock could increase their profits by cutting out the cost of manufacturing the socks. This could be beneficial for the company as it would reduce costs and increase their profits. However, there are several factors that should be taken into consideration. Firstly, the Endure process may be a major selling point for Dura-Sock and removing it could be detrimental to their brand image. Additionally, the customers may not be aware of the cost savings that would be realized by eliminating the Endure process, and may be unwilling to purchase the socks if they are aware of the cost savings. Furthermore, the argument does not take into account any potential long-term costs associated with the elimination of the Endure process, such as customer dissatisfaction or decreased quality. \n\nIn conclusion, while the argument presented in the memo suggests that Dura-Sock could increase their profits by eliminating their Endure manufacturing process, there are several factors that should be taken into consideration. The potential cost savings should be weighed against the potential long-term costs, as well as the potential impact on the brand image and customer satisfaction.", "esl_essay": "The argument presented in the memo depends on several assumptions. First, it assumes that the costumers' survey is accurate and reflects the preferences of the company's costumers in general. Second, it assumes that the Endure manufacturing process is the sole factor in the costumers' decision to purchase new socks. Finally, it assumes that the Endure process is not necessary for the socks' durability.\n\nIf any of these assumptions prove unwarranted, then the argument that the company should discontinue the Endure process is not valid. For example, if the survey is not representative of the company's costumers' preferences, then the argument is based on false premises and should not be accepted. Additionally, if the Endure process is in fact necessary for the socks' durability, then discontinuing it could result in a decrease in the quality of the socks and thus a decrease in customer satisfaction."}

Installing software on company computers to detect employees' Internet use is the best way to prevent employees from wasting time on the job. This could lead to higher quality work and more efficient use of resources. Additionally, it could help the company save money by preventing employees from engaging in activities that are not related to work, such as online shopping or playing games. \n\nOn the other hand, this policy could be seen as a violation of employee privacy, as it would give the company access to personal information about their employees. {"index": 372, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a letter from a firm providing investment advice for a client.\n\"Most homes in the northeastern United States, where winters are typically cold, have traditionally used oil as their major fuel for heating. Last heating season that region experienced 90 days with below-normal temperatures, and climate forecasters predict that this weather pattern will continue for several more years. Furthermore, many new homes are being built in the region in response to recent population growth. Because of these trends, we predict an increased demand for heating oil and recommend investment in Consolidated Industries, one of whose major business operations is the retail sale of home heating oil.\"\nWrite a response in which you examine the stated and/or unstated assumptions of the argument. Be sure to explain how the argument depends on these assumptions and what the implications are for the argument if the assumptions prove unwarranted.", "aae_prompt": "The prompt you've provided is written in a formal, academic style that is characteristic of Standard American English. African-American English (AAE), also known as African-American Vernacular English (AAVE), is a dialect of English with its own grammatical, phonological, and lexical patterns. It's important to note that AAE is a legitimate and rule-governed dialect, but it is often stigmatized and misunderstood. \n\nWhen translating into AAE, it's crucial to avoid perpetuating stereotypes or reducing the dialect to a collection of slang terms. AAE is a complex linguistic system with its own rules and should be treated with respect. However, it's also important to recognize that AAE is not typically used in formal writing, and translating a formal essay prompt into AAE could be seen as inappropriate or could inadvertently perpetuate linguistic prejudice.\n\nThat said, I can provide a version that attempts to capture some elements of AAE while maintaining the formality of the original prompt. Please note that this is a sensitive task and that AAE varies widely among speakers, so there is no single way to rewrite the prompt in AAE.\n\nHere's an attempt to rewrite the prompt with some features that might be found in AAE, while still keeping it in a formal register:\n\n\"The letter we got from this investment advice place say that most houses up in the northeast part of the U.S., where it be cold in the winter, they usually be using oil to keep warm. Last winter, they had like 90 days when it was colder than usual, and them folks who predict the weather say this kinda thing gon' keep up for a few more years. Plus, they building a bunch of new homes 'cause more people moving there. With all this going on, we thinking it's gon' be a bigger need for heating oil, so we saying y'all should put some money into Consolidated Industries, 'cause they be selling that heating oil for houses.\n\nNow, you gotta look at what they assuming in what they saying. Make sure you explain how they argument leaning on these assumptions, and what it mean for they argument if these assumptions ain't holding up.\"\n\nPlease remember that this translation is a very rough approximation and may not accurately reflect the nuances of AAE. It's also important to approach such translations with cultural sensitivity and an understanding of the context in which AAE is used.", "esl_prompt": "The following appeared in a letter from a firm providing investment advice for a client.\n\"Most homes in the northeastern United States, where winters is typically cold, have traditionally used oil as their major fuel for heating. Last heating season that region experienced 90 days with below-normal temperatures, and climate forecasters are predicting that this weather pattern will continue for several more years. Furthermore, many new homes is being built in the region in response to recent population growth. Because of these trends, we predicts an increased demand for heating oil and recommend investment in Consolidated Industries, one of whose major business operations is the retail sale of home heating oil.\"\nWrite a response in which you examine the stated and/or unstated assumptions of the argument. Be sure to explain how the argument is depending on these assumptions and what the implications are for the argument if the assumptions prove unwarranted.", "sae_essay": "The argument presented in the letter depends on several assumptions about the northeastern United States, its climate, and the home heating industry. The first assumption is that the northeastern United States will continue to experience 90 days with below-normal temperatures for several more years. This prediction is based on climate forecasts, which are notoriously difficult to make and often inaccurate. If the prediction is wrong, then the argument that there will be an increased demand for heating oil and that investment in Consolidated Industries is a wise choice is invalid. \n\nThe second assumption is that the population growth in the northeastern United States will result in an increased demand for home heating oil. This is a difficult assumption to evaluate, as it depends on the rate of population growth and the amount of energy-efficiency measures taken by homeowners. If the population growth is not as high as predicted or if homeowners take more energy-efficient measures, then the demand for heating oil may not increase as predicted.\n\nThe third assumption is that Consolidated Industries is a wise investment choice. This is a difficult assumption to evaluate, as there are many other companies in the home heating oil industry. It is possible that another company may be more efficient or have a better business model than Consolidated Industries. Investors should research other companies in the industry before making an investment decision.", "aae_essay": "The prompt you've provided is written in a formal, academic style that is characteristic of Standard American English. African-American English (AAE), also known as African-American Vernacular English (AAVE), is a dialect of English with its own grammatical, phonological, and lexical patterns. It's important to note that AAE is a legitimate and rule-governed dialect, but it is often stigmatized and misunderstood. \n\nWhen translating into AAE, it's crucial to avoid perpetuating stereotypes or reducing the dialect to a collection of slang terms. AAE is a complex linguistic system with its own rules and should be treated with respect. However, it's also important to recognize that AAE is not typically used in formal writing, and translating a formal essay prompt into AAE could be seen as inappropriate or could inadvertently perpetuate linguistic prejudice. \n\nThat said, I can provide a version that attempts to capture some elements of AAE while maintaining the formality of the original prompt. Please note that this is a sensitive task and that AAE varies widely among speakers, so there is no single way to rewrite the prompt in AAE. \n\nHere's an attempt to rewrite the prompt with some features that might be found in AAE, while still keeping it in a formal register: \n\n\"The letter we got from this investment advice place say that most houses up in the northeast part of the U.S., where it be cold in the winter, they usually be using oil to keep warm. Last winter, they had like 90 days when it was colder than usual, and them folks who predict the weather say this kinda thing gon' keep up for a few more years. Plus, they building a bunch of new homes 'cause more people moving there. With all this going on, we thinking it's gon' be a bigger need for heating oil, so we saying y'all should put some money into Consolidated Industries, 'cause they be selling that heating oil for houses. \n\nNow, you gotta look at what they assuming in what they saying. Make sure you explain how they argument leaning on these assumptions, and what it mean for they argument if these assumptions ain't holding up.\"", "esl_essay": "The argument presented in the letter is based on several assumptions. The first assumption is that the northeastern United States will experience below-normal temperatures for the foreseeable future, which is based on climate forecasts. The second assumption is that there will be an increased demand for heating oil due to the recent population growth in the region. The third assumption is that Consolidated Industries is well-positioned to meet this increased demand.\n\nIf any of these assumptions prove unwarranted, then the argument that investment in Consolidated Industries is a good idea may be weakened. For example, if the climate forecasts are incorrect and the region experiences above-normal temperatures, then there will be less demand for heating oil and Consolidated Industries may not be able to meet the demand. Additionally, if the population growth in the region does not continue, then the increased demand for heating oil may not materialize and Consolidated Industries' investment may not be profitable."}
{"index": 373, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in an article in the Grandview Beacon.\n\"For many years the city of Grandview has provided annual funding for the Grandview Symphony. Last year, however, private contributions to the symphony increased by 200 percent and attendance at the symphony's concerts-in-the-park series doubled. The symphony has also announced an increase in ticket prices for next year. Given such developments, some city commissioners argue that the symphony can now be fully self-supporting, and they recommend that funding for the symphony be eliminated from next year's budget.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what questions would need to be answered in order to decide whether the recommendation and the argument on which it is based are reasonable. Be sure to explain how the answers to these questions would help to evaluate the recommendation.", "aae_prompt": "Check it, dis came out in a piece in da Grandview Beacon. \"Fo' a good minute, Grandview been throwin' dough at the Grandview Symphony every year. {"index": 374, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a memo from the director of a large group of hospitals.\n\"In a laboratory study of liquid antibacterial hand soaps, a concentrated solution of UltraClean produced a 40 percent greater reduction in the bacteria population than did the liquid hand soaps currently used in our hospitals. And that will reduce the incidence of heart disease in the general population.\nWrite a response in which you examine the stated and/or unstated assumptions of the argument. Be sure to explain how the argument depends on these assumptions and what the implications are for the argument if the assumptions prove unwarranted.", "sae_essay": "The argument that pet ownership leads to longer, healthier lives and that Sherwood Hospital should form a partnership with Sherwood Animal Shelter to institute an adopt-a-dog program is based on several assumptions. The first assumption is that pet ownership in general, and dog ownership in particular, leads to longer, healthier lives. This assumption is based on the results of a recent study which showed that pet owners have lower incidences of heart disease. The second assumption is that the adopt-a-dog program will be successful in reducing the incidence of heart disease in patients recovering from heart disease. This assumption is based on the idea that the program will encourage dog ownership, which will reduce the chance of heart disease and also reduce the need for ongoing treatment. The third assumption is that the publicity about the adopt-a-dog program will encourage more people to adopt pets from the shelter, which will reduce the incidence of heart disease in the general population. This assumption is based on the idea that people are more likely to take better care of their pets if they adopt them from a shelter, rather than buying them from a breeder or other source. \n\nThe implications of these assumptions are that the adopt-a-dog program will lead to longer, healthier lives for patients recovering from heart disease, as well as a reduction in the incidence of heart disease in the general population. The implications of this argument are that Sherwood Hospital should form a partnership with Sherwood Animal Shelter to promote the adopt-a-dog program. {"index": 384, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a letter to the editor of a Batavia newspaper.\n\"The department of agriculture in Batavia reports that the number of dairy farms throughout the country is now 25 percent greater than it was 10 years ago. Second, what are the current trends in the market for low-fat products? Are low-fat products really being sought after by the majority of consumers, or is this just a temporary fad? Third, what are the nutritional benefits of low-fat products compared to the high-fat products produced by Old Dairy Industries? Finally, what are the long-term implications of the advice to sell or avoid investing in Old Dairy Industries? \n\nAnswering these questions would help to determine whether the advice is reasonable and whether it is in the best interest of investors to follow it.", "aae_essay": "To determine whether the advice given in the newsletter is sound, we need to ask a few questions. First, what is the definition of \u201clow-fat\u201d? Is it a certain percentage of fat or cholesterol that is considered low? Second, what is the current trend in the market for low-fat products? Are people actually buying them, or is the demand for them decreasing? Third, what is the current demand for products from Old Dairy Industries? Are their sales decreasing, and if so, why? Finally, what are the long-term implications of following the advice given in the newsletter? Will it be beneficial or detrimental to investors? \n\nAnswering these questions will help us determine if the advice is sound and whether or not it is a good idea to follow it. If the demand for low-fat products is decreasing and the demand for Old Dairy Industries\u2019 products is decreasing, then it is likely that following the advice will lead to a decrease in profits. Therefore, it is not advisable to invest in Old Dairy Industries at this time.", "esl_essay": "In order to evaluate the advice given in the newsletter, it is important to consider several questions. First, what is the source of the survey that indicates the majority of people want to reduce their intake of foods with fats and cholesterol? Is the survey representative of the general population? Second, what are the current trends in the market for low-fat products? Are low-fat products really being sought after by the majority of consumers, or is this just a fad? Third, what are the nutritional benefits of low-fat products compared to the high-fat products produced by Old Dairy Industries? {"index": 391, "sae_prompt": "The following is a letter to the editor of an environmental magazine.\n\"In 1975 a wildlife census found that there were seven species of amphibians in Xanadu National Park, with abundant numbers of each species. However, in 2002 only four species of amphibians were observed in the park, and the numbers of each species were drastically reduced. There has been a substantial decline in the numbers of amphibians worldwide, and global pollution of water and air is clearly implicated. The decline of amphibians in Xanadu National Park, however, almost certainly has a different cause: in 1975, trout \u2014 which are known to eat amphibian eggs \u2014 were introduced into the park.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "aae_prompt": "Check it, dis a letter to the editor for a magazine 'bout the environment.\n\nBack in '75, folks counted up like seven kinds of them hoppy critters, amphibians, in Xanadu National Park, and they was all over the place. But come 2002, they only peeped four kinds, and they numbers was way down. We know all 'round the world them amphibians been droppin' off, and dirty water and air is for real part of the mess. But the thing with Xanadu National Park, it's prolly got its own thing goin' on: in '75, they dropped trout in the park, and them fish be munchin' on amphibian eggs.\n\nYo, write up somethin' 'bout what kinda proof you'd need to check out this here argument, and break down how that proof gon' make the argument less solid or more tight.", "esl_prompt": "The following is a letter to the editor of an environmental magazine.\n\"In 1975 a wildlife census find that there was seven species of amphibians in Xanadu National Park, with abundant number of each species. But, in 2002 only four species of amphibians was observed in the park, and the numbers of each species was drastically reduced. There has been a substantial decline in the numbers of amphibians worldwide, and global pollution of water and air is clearly implicated. The decline of amphibians in Xanadu National Park, however, almost certainly has a different cause: in 1975, trouts \u2014 which are known to eat amphibian eggs \u2014 was introduced into the park.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidences is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidences would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "sae_essay": "The argument presented is that the decline of amphibians in Xanadu National Park is due to global pollution, but the introduction of trout into the park in 1975 could be a potential contributing factor. To evaluate this argument, evidence is needed to determine the exact population numbers of amphibians in the park before and after the introduction of trout. If the numbers of amphibians were significantly higher before the introduction of trout, this would weaken the argument that global pollution is the primary cause of the decline in amphibians in the park. On the other hand, if the numbers of amphibians were significantly lower after the introduction of trout, this would strengthen the argument that the introduction of trout is the primary cause of the decline.", "aae_essay": "In order to evaluate the argument that the drop in amphibian populations in Xanadu National Park is due to the introduction of trout, one would need to collect data on the number of amphibians in the park before and after the introduction of the trout. This data can be collected through surveys of the park\u2019s wildlife, or by examining records of amphibian populations in nearby areas that have not had trout introduced. Additionally, one could look at the effects of trout introduction on other aquatic species, such as fish, to see if the introduction of trout has had a negative effect on amphibians. If the data shows a decrease in amphibian populations in the park after the introduction of trout, then this would provide evidence to support the argument that the drop in amphibian populations is due to the introduction of trout.", "esl_essay": "The argument presented is that the decline of amphibians in Xanadu National Park is due to global pollution, but the introduction of trouts in 1975, which is known to eat amphibian eggs, could be a more likely cause. To evaluate this argument, evidence is needed to show the amount of trouts in the park in 1975 and the amount of amphibians present at that time. If the amount of trouts is known, then the amount of amphibians can be compared to determine if the amount of amphibians was reduced due to the introduction of trouts. If the amount of trouts is not known, then this evidence would weaken the argument. Additionally, evidence is needed to show the amount of amphibians in the park in 2002, to compare the amount of amphibians in 1975 and 2002. This evidence would strengthen the argument."}
{"index": 392, "sae_prompt": "The following is a letter to the editor of an environmental magazine.\n\"Two studies of amphibians in Xanadu National Park confirm a significant decline in the numbers of amphibians. While the introduction of trout may have had an effect on the amphibians, it is likely that other factors are also at play. \n\nOne potential factor is habitat destruction. The park may have undergone changes in land use or development since 1975, which could have led to a decrease in the amount of suitable amphibian habitat. Additionally, climate change could be playing a role, as warmer temperatures may be negatively impacting the survival of amphibians. \n\nAnother factor to consider is the introduction of invasive species. First, it assumes that Delany Personnel Firm is better than Walsh Personnel Firm, as evidenced by their differing track records. This assumption is based on the fact that Delany has a larger staff and more branch offices, which suggests that they are more capable of providing better services. Second, it assumes that the clients of both firms are comparable, which is based on the fact that both firms were hired to provide assistance to laid-off employees. Lastly, it assumes that the clients of both firms took the same amount of time to find jobs, which is based on the data provided. \n\nIf any of these assumptions prove to be false, then the argument presented in the memo will be weakened. For example, if Delany is better than Walsh but the clients of both firms are not comparable, then the argument that Delany is superior to Walsh would be invalid. Additionally, if the clients of both firms took different amounts of time to find jobs, then the argument that Delany is superior to Walsh would also be invalid.", "aae_essay": "The argument presented in the memo is based on the assumption that Delany Personnel Firm is better than Walsh Personnel Firm, as evidenced by the fact that those who used Delany's services found work faster than those who didn't. This assumption is supported by the statement that those who used Delany found work within six months, while those who used Walsh took nine months. However, this comparison is flawed because it does not take into account the number of people who used each firm, or the amount of time each firm had to find jobs for their clients. Without more information, it is impossible to say which firm is better, and the argument presented in the memo is weakened.", "esl_essay": "The argument presented in the memo depends on several assumptions. This implies that Delany is more effective than Walsh, but it does not necessarily mean that Delany is necessarily better than other firms. \n\nSecond, the argument assumes that the clients of Delany and Walsh are comparable. It is possible that Delany's clients are more motivated or better prepared for job searches than Walsh's clients, or that Delany's larger staff and larger number of branch offices gives them an advantage. Without evidence to the contrary, it is impossible to know if the memo's conclusion is valid. \n\nFinally, the argument assumes that the clients of both Delany and Walsh will be laid off from XYZ. {"index": 403, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a memo from the new vice president of Sartorian, a company that manufactures men's clothing.\n\"Five years ago, at a time when we had difficulty obtaining reliable supplies of high-quality wool fabric, we discontinued production of our popular alpaca overcoat. First, it assumes that there is a high demand for alpaca overcoats and that this demand has not changed in the five years since Sartorian stopped producing them. Second, it assumes that the company's new fabric supplier can provide reliable supplies of high-quality wool fabric. Finally, it assumes that Sartorian's alpaca overcoats are unique and that there are no competitors offering a comparable product. \nIf any of these assumptions prove unwarranted, the argument that Sartorian should resume production of alpaca overcoats is weakened. For example, if the demand for alpaca overcoats has decreased in the five years since they were discontinued, or if there are now competitors offering a comparable product, then the argument is not as strong. Additionally, if the new fabric supplier is unable to provide reliable supplies of high-quality wool fabric, then Sartorian may not be able to produce alpaca overcoats to the same quality that customers have come to expect. \nOverall, the argument presented in the memo depends on several assumptions that must be examined to determine the strength of the argument. If the assumptions prove unwarranted, then the conclusion that Sartorian should resume production of alpaca overcoats may not be warranted.", "aae_essay": "Sartorian is assuming that there is still a demand for their alpaca overcoats, despite them being off the market for the past few years. They are also assuming that the price of clothes has increased, which will make their overcoats more desirable to customers. Finally, they are assuming that their competitors do not have anything similar to their alpaca overcoats, which will give them an advantage in the market.\n\nIf these assumptions do not hold up, then Sartorian's game plan may not be successful. If the demand for their overcoats has decreased, then they may not be able to make as much money as they had hoped. First, it assumes that the new fabric supplier can provide reliable supplies of high-quality wool fabric. This assumption is critical to the argument that Sartorian can resume production of their popular alpaca overcoat. Second, it assumes that there is a pent-up demand for Sartorian's alpaca overcoats, which has not been met by other companies. Finally, it assumes that the overall increase in clothing prices will make Sartorian's alpaca overcoats more profitable than ever before.\n\nIf any of these assumptions prove unwarranted, then the argument presented in the memo may not be valid. Additionally, if there is not a pent-up demand for Sartorian's alpaca overcoats, then the argument that they can expect increased profits may not be valid. Finally, if the overall increase in clothing prices does not make Sartorian's alpaca overcoats more profitable than ever before, then the argument presented in the memo may not be valid."}

{"index": 409, "sae_prompt": "There is now evidence that the relaxed pace of life in small towns promotes better health and greater longevity than does the hectic pace of life in big cities. {"index": 415, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a memo from the business manager of a chain of cheese stores located throughout the United States.\n\"For many years all the stores in our chain have stocked a wide variety of both domestic and imported cheeses. Last year, however, all of the five best-selling cheeses at our newest store were domestic cheddar cheeses from Wisconsin. Furthermore, a recent survey by Cheeses of the World magazine indicates an increasing preference for domestic cheeses among its subscribers. Since our company can reduce expenses by limiting inventory, the best way to improve profits in all of our stores is to discontinue stocking many of our varieties of imported cheese and concentrate primarily on domestic cheeses.\"\nWrite a response in which you examine the stated and/or unstated assumptions of the argument. Since we can cut down on what we spend by not havin' so much stuff in stock, the slickest move to make more paper in all our stores is to stop fillin' the shelves with so many kinds of imported cheese and just focus on the ones from the crib.\"\n\nAight, now you gotta break down what they assumin' in this here argument. Last year, however, all of the five best-selling cheeses at our newest store was domestic cheddar cheeses from Wisconsin. Furthermore, a recent survey by Cheeses of the World magazine indicates an increasing preference for domestic cheeses among its subscribers. Since our company can reduce expenses by limiting inventory, the best way to improve profits in all of our stores is to discontinue stocking many of our varieties of imported cheese and concentrate primarily on domestic cheeses.\"\nWrite a response in which you examine the stated and/or unstated assumptions of the argument. Be sure to explain how the argument depends on these assumptions and what the implications are for the argument if the assumptions prove unwarranted.", "sae_essay": "The argument presented in the memo depends on several assumptions. First, it assumes that the survey conducted by Cheeses of the World magazine is accurate and that it reflects a true trend in consumer preference. Second, it assumes that the best-selling cheeses at the newest store are indicative of consumer preference across all stores. Finally, it assumes that discontinuing the stocking of imported cheeses will result in increased profits for the chain of cheese stores.\n\nIf any of these assumptions prove unwarranted, the argument presented in the memo may not be valid. For example, if the survey conducted by Cheeses of the World is not accurate, then the argument may be based on false information and the conclusion that domestic cheeses are preferred may not be true. Additionally, if the best-selling cheeses at the newest store are not indicative of consumer preference across all stores, then the argument may not be valid. Finally, if discontinuing the stocking of imported cheeses does not result in increased profits for the chain of cheese stores, then the argument may not be valid.", "aae_essay": "The argument presented in the memo is based on the assumption that domestic cheeses are becoming more popular and that focusing on cheeses from the United States will help the stores save money and make more profit. This assumption is based on the results of the survey conducted by Cheeses of the World magazine, which suggests that people are becoming more and more interested in domestic cheeses. \n\nThe argument also assumes that by reducing the number of imported cheeses in the stores, they will be able to save money on what they spend. This assumption is based on the idea that imported cheeses are more expensive than domestic cheeses and that by reducing the number of imported cheeses, they can reduce their overall costs. \n\nThe argument presented in the memo is flawed because it does not take into account the fact that there are other types of cheeses besides domestic and imported. It also does not consider the fact that some imported cheeses may be just as popular as domestic cheeses and may actually be more profitable. Furthermore, it does not consider the fact that reducing the number of cheeses in the stores may lead to a decrease in sales and therefore less profit.", "esl_essay": "The argument presented in the memo depends on several assumptions. First, it assumes that the survey conducted by Cheeses of the World magazine is accurate in its assessment of the preferences of its subscribers. Second, it assumes that the best-selling cheeses at the newest store are indicative of a larger trend in the market. Finally, it assumes that discontinuing the stocking of imported cheeses and concentrating on domestic cheeses will result in improved profits for the chain of cheese stores.\n\nIf any of these assumptions prove unwarranted, then the argument presented in the memo is weakened. For example, if the survey conducted by Cheeses of the World is not accurate in its assessment of the preferences of its subscribers, then the argument that there is an increasing preference for domestic cheeses may not be valid. Additionally, if the best-selling cheeses at the newest store are not indicative of a larger trend in the market, then discontinuing the stocking of imported cheeses may not result in improved profits for the chain of cheese stores."}
{"index": 416, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a memo from the owner of a chain of cheese stores located throughout the United States.\n\"For many years all the stores in our chain have stocked a wide variety of both domestic and imported cheeses. {"index": 421, "sae_prompt": "The following is a recommendation from the personnel director to the president of Acme Publishing Company.\n\"Many other companies have recently stated that having their employees take the Easy Read Speed-Reading Course has greatly improved productivity. One graduate of the course was able to read a 500-page report in only two hours; another graduate rose from an assistant manager to vice president of the company in under a year. Obviously, the faster you can read, the more information you can absorb in a single workday. Moreover, Easy Read would cost Acme only $500 per employee \u2014 a small price to pay when you consider the benefits. Included in this fee is a three-week seminar in Spruce City and a lifelong subscription to the Easy Read newsletter. {"index": 427, "sae_prompt": "Evidence suggests that academic honor codes, which call for students to agree not to cheat in their academic endeavors and to notify a faculty member if they suspect that others have cheated, are far more successful than are other methods at deterring cheating among students at colleges and universities. Several years ago, Groveton College adopted such a code and discontinued its old-fashioned system in which teachers closely monitored students. Under the old system, teachers reported an average of thirty cases of cheating per year. In the first year the honor code was in place, students reported twenty-one cases of cheating; five years later, this figure had dropped to fourteen. Moreover, in a recent survey, a majority of Groveton students said that they would be less likely to cheat with an honor code in place than without.\nWrite a response in which you discuss one or more alternative explanations that could rival the proposed explanation and explain how your explanation(s) can plausibly account for the facts presented in the argument.", "aae_prompt": "Evidence out there showin' that them academic honor codes, where students gotta promise not to cheat on they schoolwork and to holla at a teacher if they think somebody else cheatin', work way better than other ways to stop cheatin' at colleges and universities. A while back, Groveton College got on board with one of them codes and cut out they old-school way where teachers had to keep a tight watch on students. Back in them days, teachers would catch like thirty students cheatin' every year. But then, when they started with the honor code, students called out twenty-one cheatin' cases in the first year; and then, after five years, that number fell to just fourteen. Plus, in a survey they did not too long ago, most of the Groveton students said they ain't as likely to cheat if there's an honor code than if there ain't one.\n\nWrite up somethin' where you talk 'bout one or more different reasons that might explain this thing just as good, if not better, than what they sayin'. Additionally, the honor code encourages a culture of honesty and respect among the students, as they are all held to the same standards and must police one another. This creates a sense of community and mutual respect that may be lacking in a system where students fear being caught by their teachers. \n\nFurthermore, the honor code may have also helped to reduce the pressure on teachers to police their students. With the code in place, teachers can focus more of their energy on teaching and less on policing their students. With the honor code in place, students now feel more comfortable coming forward when they suspect cheating, knowing that their peers will be held accountable. \n\nFinally, the honor code may have simply been effective in reducing cheating because it is a more effective method of enforcement than the old system of teacher monitoring. Teachers are able to catch cheating more quickly and efficiently with an honor code in place, and students are more likely to be caught and punished for cheating. This may be enough to deter students from cheating."}

These results demonstrate that bicyclists feeling safer because they are wearing helmets, and they take more risks as a result. Thus there is clearly a call for the government to strive to reduce the number of serious injuries from bicycle accidents by launching an education program that concentrates on the factors other than helmet use that are necessary for bicycle safety.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is need to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "sae_essay": "The argument presented in the health newsletter is that the increased use of helmets by bicyclists has led to an increase in the number of bicycle accidents, as bicyclists feel safer and take more risks due to the helmets. Additionally, evidence is needed to show the percentage of bicyclists taking risks before and after. This evidence would help to determine whether the increase in helmet use is the sole cause of the increase in accidents, or if other factors such as increased risk-taking are also to blame.", "aae_essay": "In order to evaluate the argument that wearing helmets is the sole cause of the decrease in bike-related injuries, it is important to look at the evidence presented. While the study cited in the newsletter does show an increase in helmet usage and a decrease in bike-related injuries, it does not provide any evidence to suggest that helmets are the sole cause of this decrease. For example, if customers can tell the difference between butter and margarine, or if customers are bothered by the switch, then the argument does not hold up and the switch should not be made. Additionally, if margarine is not actually cheaper than butter, then the argument does not hold up and the switch should not be made. \n\nOverall, the argument from the business manager at Happy Pancake House relies heavily on a few assumptions that must be examined to determine if the conclusion should be accepted.", "esl_essay": "The argument presented in the memorandum from the business manager of Happy Pancake House restaurants assumes that customers cannot distinguish butter from margarine and that the term 'butter' can be used to refer to either butter or margarine. These assumptions are critical to the argument that the cost-saving change should be extended to the rest of the country, as it implies that customers will not be able to tell the difference. However, these assumptions are not necessarily true. While it is possible that some customers may not be able to tell the difference between butter and margarine, it is also possible that some customers will be able to tell the difference and will be dissatisfied with the change. Furthermore, the term 'butter' may not be used to refer to both butter and margarine in all cases. Therefore, the argument presented does not necessarily hold true and should be examined further."}

{"index": 445, "sae_prompt": "While the Department of Education in the state of Attra recommends that high school students be assigned homework every day, the data from a recent statewide survey of high school math and science teachers give us reason to question the usefulness of daily homework. In the district of Sanlee, 86 percent of the teachers reported assigning homework three to five times a week, whereas in the district of Marlee, less than 25 percent of the teachers reported assigning homework three to five times a week. Yet the students in Marlee earn better grades overall and are less likely to be required to repeat a year of school than are the students in Sanlee. Therefore, all teachers in our high schools should assign homework no more than twice a week.\nWrite a response in which you examine the stated and/or unstated assumptions of the argument. Still, them kids in Marlee be gettin' better grades on the whole and they ain't as likely to have to do a school year over compared to them kids in Sanlee.
