{"index": 446, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared as an editorial in the student newspaper of Groveton College.\n\"To combat the recently reported dramatic rise in cheating among college students, colleges and universities should adopt honor codes similar to Groveton's, which calls for students to agree not to cheat in their academic endeavors and to notify a faculty member if they suspect that others have cheated. Groveton's honor code replaced an old-fashioned system in which teachers closely monitored students. Under that system, teachers reported an average of thirty cases of cheating per year. The honor code has proven far more successful: in the first year it was in place, students reported twenty-one cases of cheating; five years later, this figure had dropped to fourteen. Moreover, in a recent survey conducted by the Groveton honor council, a majority of students said that they would be less likely to cheat with an honor code in place than without.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "aae_prompt": "The followin' popped up as an editorial in the student paper at Groveton College.\n\"To deal wit' the big jump in cheatin' 'mong college students that folks been talkin' 'bout lately, colleges and universities oughta get on board wit' honor codes like the one Groveton got, where students gotta promise they ain't gon' cheat in they school work and they gotta tell a teacher if they think somebody else doin' wrong. At a recent faculty meeting, a majority of faculty members vote in favor of coeducation, arguing that it would encourage more students for apply to Grove. However, Grove students, both past and present, are against the idea of coeducation. Eighty percent of the students responding to a survey conducted by the student government wanted the school to remain all female, and over half of the alumnae who answered a separate survey also opposed coeducation. Therefore, we recommend to maintain Grove College's tradition of all-female education. We predict that keeping the college all-female will improve morale among students and convince alumnae to keep supporting the college financially.\"\n\nWrite a response in which you discuss what questions would need to be answer in order to decide whether the recommendation is likely to have the predicted result. Answering these questions would help to evaluate the recommendation to maintain Grove College's tradition of all-female education.", "aae_essay": "To determine whether Grove College should continue to be an all-women's school, it is important to consider both the pros and cons of the current system and the proposed coeducational system. \n\nOn the one hand, the all-women's system has the potential to create a more comfortable and supportive learning environment for the students. Women-only institutions have been shown to provide a sense of community and safety that may not be present in coeducational institutions. Additionally, the alumnae of all-women's schools often have a strong sense of loyalty and connection to the school, which can lead to more donations and support. \n\nOn the other hand, the proposed coeducational system could bring more students to Grove College, potentially increasing the quality of the education and resources available. Additionally, it could open up more opportunities for students to interact with the opposite gender, which could lead to more diverse perspectives and experiences. \n\nTo determine which system is best for Grove College, it is important to consider the answers to the following questions: \n\n1. How will the current students and alumnae feel about the change? \n2. How will the quality of the education and resources available to students change with the switch? \n3. How will the interactions between the opposite genders be affected by the switch? \n4. How will the donations and support from alumnae be impacted? \n5. What are the long-term implications of the switch? \n\nAnswering these questions will help to determine whether the proposed switch to a coeducational system is the best choice for Grove College.", "esl_essay": "In order to decide whether the recommendation is likely to have the predicted result, it is important to consider several questions. First, what are the potential benefits of coeducation? Would admitting male students increase the number of applicants to Grove College? Would it lead to better academic performance? Would it improve morale among students and convince alumnae to keep supporting the college financially? Additionally, what are the potential drawbacks of coeducation? Could it lead to increased gender tension on campus? Could it lead to a decrease in academic performance? Could it alienate alumnae who are opposed to coeducation? \n\nAnswering these questions would help to evaluate the recommendation. If the potential benefits of coeducation outweigh the potential drawbacks, then it is likely that the recommendation will have the predicted result."}

{"index": 469, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a memo from a budget planner for the city of Grandview.\n\"It is time for the city of Grandview to stop funding the Grandview Symphony Orchestra. Be sure to explain how the answers to these questions would help to evaluate the recommendation.", "aae_prompt": "The followin' popped up in a memo from the mayor of Brindleburg to the city council.\n\"Bout two years back, the town of Seaside Vista done opened up a brand new municipal golf course and resort hotel. {"index": 483, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a memo from New Ventures Consulting to the president of HobCo, Inc., a chain of hobby shops.\n\"Our team has completed its research on suitable building sites for a new HobCo hobby Shop in the city of Grilldon. This could be done by producing more cream than the market can bear and then setting the price higher than it would be otherwise. {"index": 489, "sae_prompt": "Archaeologists have long thought that an artifact called the pemchint was used by Dodecan people solely as a musical instrument. Pemchints consist of hollowed pieces of bone, shell, or wood that are tied together with long straps. When whirled in the air, the pemchints create pleasant tones. Until recently, pemchints were found only at locations known to be used for Dodecan rituals and celebrations. Additionally, they were always excavated in proximity to other musical artifacts. Recently, however, a pemchint was found along with Dodecan hunters' tools located miles from the nearest known Dodecan settlement, while no other music-related objects were found in the area. Be sure to explain how the argument depends on these assumptions and what the implications are for the argument if the assumptions prove unwarranted.", "sae_essay": "The argument presented in the letter depends on several assumptions. First, it assumes that the number of real estate agents and the size of the firm are the primary factors in determining the success of a real estate firm. This implies that larger firms with more agents will always be more successful than smaller firms. However, this is not necessarily the case; smaller firms may be able to provide more personalized service and may have access to unique listings that larger firms do not. Additionally, the argument assumes that the size of the firm's revenue and the average sale price of homes listed with the firm are reliable indicators of its success. This assumes that all other factors, such as the quality of service, are equal between the two firms. Finally, the argument assumes that the speed of sale is the sole factor in determining the success of a real estate firm. This ignores other factors, such as the quality of the listing and the market conditions at the time of the sale. \n\nIf any of these assumptions are not true, then the argument presented in the letter is weakened. For example, if the quality of service offered by Fitch Realty is superior to that of Adams Realty, then the argument would be weakened. Additionally, if the market conditions at the time of the sale are not favorable for either firm, then the argument would be weakened.", "aae_essay": "Adams Realty and Fitch Realty are two real estate companies in the same neighborhood. According to the letter, Adams Realty has 40 real estate agents compared to Fitch Realty's 25 agents. Additionally, Adams Realty reported double the sales of Fitch Realty last year, with an average sale price of $168,000 compared to Fitch's $144,000. Furthermore, the letter claims that houses listed with Adams Realty sell quicker, with a four-month difference between the two companies. \n\nThe letter is implying that Adams Realty is the superior real estate company in the neighborhood, but there are a few things to consider. First, the number of agents does not necessarily determine the quality of service. While Adams Realty has more agents, it is possible that Fitch Realty's 25 agents are more experienced and thus more successful. Additionally, the letter does not mention the size of the houses or the location of the houses, which could also affect the sales price. Finally, the four-month difference in sales could be due to a variety of factors, such as the type of houses listed or the market conditions at the time. \n\nIn conclusion, while Adams Realty may have more agents and higher sales, it is impossible to say that they are the superior real estate company without more information.", "esl_essay": "The argument presented in the letter depends on several assumptions. First, it assumes that the number of real estate agents and the size of the firm are the primary factors in determining the success of a real estate firm. This implies that larger firms with more agents will always be more successful than smaller firms. However, this is not necessarily the case; smaller firms may be able to provide more personalized service and may have access to unique listings that larger firms do not. Additionally, the argument assumes that the revenue and average sale price of a firm are reliable indicators of its success. However, other factors such as the number of transactions or the total market share of the firm may be more meaningful measures of success. Finally, the argument assumes that Adams Realty is always better than Fitch Realty, which may not always be the case. Other factors, such as the location of the homes or the preferences of individual buyers and sellers, may be more important than the size of the firm."}
{"index": 495, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in a letter to the editor of the Balmer Island Gazette.\n\"On Balmer Island, where mopeds serve as a popular form of transportation, the population increases to 100,000 during the summer months. By limiting the number of rentals, the town council will attain the 50 percent annual reduction in moped accidents that was achieved last year on the neighboring island of Seaville, when Seaville's town council enforced similar limits on moped rentals.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what questions would need to be answered in order to decide whether the recommendation is likely to have the predicted result. With over 50 rental spots currently available, there is a high demand for mopeds. This has led to a number of moped-related accidents, as well as complaints from local businesses about the number of mopeds on the road. The cap would likely reduce the number of mopeds on the road, as rental spots would be limited to 25 per day. This could lead to a decrease in the number of accidents, as there would be fewer mopeds on the road. \n\nThe cap could also have an economic impact. With fewer mopeds available for rent, rental companies may be forced to raise their prices, which could lead to an increase in the cost of mopeds for tourists. This could lead to a decrease in tourism on the island, as people may be unable to afford to rent a moped. On the other hand, the cap could also lead to an increase in the number of people driving their own mopeds, which could lead to a decrease in the cost of mopeds for locals. \n\nFinally, we should consider the potential unintended consequences of the cap. If the cap is too low, it may lead to an increase in the number of people driving their own mopeds, which could lead to more pollution and a decrease in safety. Additionally, if the cap is too high, it may lead to an increase in the number of people using other forms of transportation, such as cars, which could lead to more traffic and a decrease in the number of pedestrians on the island. \n\nOverall, the cap on moped rentals on Balmer Island is a complex issue that requires careful consideration of a number of factors. We need to look at the current moped rental situation, the potential impact on moped-related accidents, the economic implications, and the potential unintended consequences. By understanding these factors, we can make an informed decision on whether the cap is a good idea or not.", "esl_essay": "In order to decide whether the recommendation is likely to have the predicted result, the following questions should be answered: \n1. {"index": 496, "sae_prompt": "Arctic deer live on islands in Canada's arctic regions. They search for food by moving over ice from island to island during the course of the year. Their habitat is limited to areas warm enough to sustain the plants on which they feed and cold enough, at least some of the year, for the ice to cover the sea separating the islands, allowing the deer to travel over it. Unfortunately, according to reports from local hunters, the deer populations are declining. Since these reports coincide with recent global warming trends that have caused the sea ice to melt, we can conclude that the purported decline in deer populations is the result of the deer's being unable to follow their age-old migration patterns across the frozen sea.\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "aae_prompt": "Arctic deer be livin' on dem islands up in Canada's arctic spots. But check it, local hunters sayin' the deer numbers droppin'. And since they talkin' 'bout this at the same time as the world gettin' warmer, makin' that sea ice melt, we thinkin' that the drop in deer numbers 'cause the deer can't do they old-school migration thing 'cross the frozen sea no more.\n\nWrite up somethin' where you talk 'bout what kinda proof we need to check out this here argument and break down how that proof gon' make the argument less solid or more tight.", "esl_prompt": "Arctic deers lives on islands in Canada's arctic regions. This evidence is supported by reports from scientists that the sea ice in the Arctic is melting, thus preventing the deer from migrating from island to island as they have done for centuries. This evidence is further supported by reports that the deer are now having to venture further and further south in order to find suitable food sources, which is not a behavior they have had to do in the past. \n\nHowever, this argument could be weakened if reports from local hunters were to contradict each other, or if reports from scientists showed that the sea ice is not in fact melting, or if reports from other sources showed that the deer are in fact thriving.", "aae_essay": "In order to evaluate the argument that Arctic deer populations are decreasing due to the melting of sea ice, we need to look at both the evidence presented and the potential implications of the melting sea ice. First, we need to consider the evidence presented by local hunters that deer numbers are indeed decreasing. This evidence is anecdotal, but it is still important to consider as it suggests that something is causing a decrease in deer populations. We can then look at scientific data to determine if there has been a decrease in sea ice in the Arctic regions, which could be causing the deer to be unable to migrate and therefore leading to a decrease in their population. \n\nIf we look at satellite data from the National Snow and Ice Data Center, we can see that the amount of sea ice in the Arctic has been steadily decreasing over the past few decades. This data shows that the amount of sea ice in the Arctic has decreased by 12.7% per decade since 1980. This decrease in sea ice could be the cause of the decrease in deer populations, as the deer are unable to migrate across the sea ice to reach food sources on other islands. \n\nThe decrease in sea ice also has implications for the environment and ecosystems in the Arctic. As the sea ice melts, it exposes more of the ocean to the sun\u2019s heat, which can cause further warming of the Arctic region and lead to further decreases in sea ice. This can cause a positive feedback loop, leading to further decreases in sea ice and further disruption of the Arctic ecosystem. \n\nOverall, the evidence presented suggests that the decrease in sea ice in the Arctic is likely causing a decrease in Arctic deer populations. This decrease in deer populations could have implications for the environment and ecosystems in the Arctic, as the deer are a key part of the food chain. For example, if the residents of Plainsville are not as health-conscious as believed, or if the demand for health-related products is not as high as expected, then Nature's Way may not be as successful as anticipated. Additionally, if the schoolchildren of Plainsville are not as interested in health and fitness as expected, then Nature's Way may not be able to capitalize on the fitness-for-life program."}
{"index": 500, "sae_prompt": "Twenty years ago, Dr. Field, a noted anthropologist, visited the island of Tertia. Using an observation-centered approach to studying Tertian culture, he concluded from his observations that children in Tertia were reared by an entire village rather than by their own biological parents. Recently another anthropologist, Dr. Karp, visited the group of islands that includes Tertia and used the interview-centered method to study child-rearing practices. In the interviews that Dr. Karp conducted with children living in this group of islands, the children spent much more time talking about their biological parents than about other adults in the village. Dr. Karp decided that Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture must be invalid. Some anthropologists recommend that to obtain accurate information on Tertian child-rearing practices, future research on the subject should be conducted via the interview-centered method.\nWrite a response in which you discuss what questions would need to be answered in order to decide whether the recommendation and the argument on which it is based are reasonable. {"index": 504, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in the Health section of the Greenhorne Gazette.\n\"Motilac is a substance that occurs naturally in the human digestive tract. This could explain why the consumption of motilac supplements in Greenhorne has increased while sales in Etolin have decreased. {"index": 510, "sae_prompt": "The following memorandum is from the business manager of Happy Pancake House restaurants.\n\"Recently, butter has been replaced by margarine in Happy Pancake House restaurants throughout the southwestern United States. This change, however, has had little impact on our customers. In fact, only about 2 percent of customers have complained, indicating that an average of 98 people out of 100 are happy with the change. Furthermore, many servers have reported that a number of customers who ask for butter do not complain when they are given margarine instead. Clearly, either these customers do not distinguish butter from margarine or they use the term 'butter' to refer to either butter or margarine.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss one or more alternative explanations that could rival the proposed explanation and explain how your explanation(s) can plausibly account for the facts presented in the argument.\n\nESL English with Errors:\n\nThe following memorandum is from the business manager of Happy Pancake House restaurants.\n\"Recently, butter has been replaced by margarine in Happy Pancake House restaurants throughout the southwestern United States. This change, however, has had little impact on our customers. In fact, only about 2 percent of customers have complained, indicating that an average of 98 people out of 100 are happy with the change. Furthermore, many servers have reported that a number of customers who ask for butter do not complain when they are given margarine instead. Clearly, either these customers do not distinguish butter from margarine or they use the term 'butter' to refer to either butter or margarine.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss one or more alternative explanations that could rival the proposed explanation and explain how your explanation(s) can plausibly account for the facts presented in the argument.", "sae_essay": "One possible explanation for the lack of complaints from customers is that the servers are not informing customers that they are being served margarine instead of butter. This could explain why customers are not noticing the change, as they are unaware that the taste and texture of their pancakes is not the same. Additionally, the customers who do complain may be a small minority, and the servers may be more likely to remember the complaints of these vocal customers. This could explain why it appears that only 2 percent of customers are dissatisfied with the change. \n\nAnother possible explanation is that customers are not as discerning as the servers and are not able to tell the difference between butter and margarine. This could explain why the customers are not noticing the change, as they do not know the difference. Additionally, it could explain why the servers are not informing customers that they are serving margarine, as they do not believe that the customers will be able to tell the difference. \n\nOverall, the lack of complaints and the servers' willingness to serve margarine instead of butter could be due to either of these two explanations or a combination of both.", "aae_essay": "The fact that only two percent of customers have been vocal about the switch from butter to margarine suggests that the majority of customers are either not aware of the change or are not bothered by it. Additionally, the waitstaff's observation that customers are not tripping up on the switch could indicate that they are not able to tell the difference between butter and margarine. This could be due to the fact that margarine is now being used in the same consistency and texture as butter, or it could be that customers are simply not as concerned with the type of fat used in their food. Furthermore, the fact that margarine is often cheaper and more accessible than butter could be another factor that is driving the switch. Ultimately, it appears that the majority of customers are not only aware of the switch, but are not bothered by it and may even be unable to tell the difference.", "esl_essay": "One possible explanation for the lack of complaints from customers is that the servers are not informing customers that the butter has been replaced with margarine. This could explain why customers are not noticing the change, as they are unaware that the product they are consuming is not butter. Furthermore, the customers who are aware of the change may be willing to accept it, as margarine is often seen as a healthier alternative to butter. This could explain why the servers have reported that some customers do not complain when they are given margarine instead of butter. \n\nAnother possible explanation is that the customers who are aware of the change are simply not as concerned about the switch from butter to margarine. This could be due to the fact that margarine is seen as a healthier alternative, or it could be that the customers do not view the change as significant enough to warrant a complaint. \n\nOverall, the lack of complaints from customers could be due to a combination of the two explanations discussed above. The servers may not be informing customers of the change, and the customers who are aware of the switch may not be as concerned about it or may not view it as significant enough to warrant a complaint."}

{"index": 514, "sae_prompt": "The following appeared in an article written by Dr. Karp, an anthropologist.\n\"Twenty years ago, Dr. Field, a noted anthropologist, visited the island of Tertia and concluded from his observations that children in Tertia were reared by an entire village rather than by their own biological parents. However, my recent interviews with children living in the group of islands that includes Tertia show that these children spend much more time talking about their biological parents than about other adults in the village. This research of mine proves that Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture is invalid and thus that the observation-centered approach to studying cultures is invalid as well. The interview-centered method that my team of graduate students is currently using in Tertia will establish a much more accurate understanding of child-rearing traditions there and in other island cultures.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss what specific evidence is needed to evaluate the argument and explain how the evidence would weaken or strengthen the argument.", "aae_prompt": "Check it, this what Dr. Karp, who be an anthropologist, had to say in one article:\n\n\"Bout twenty years back, Dr. Field, who errbody know as a big-time anthropologist, hit up Tertia island and came to the conclusion from what he peeped that the kids over there was bein' raised by the whole village, not just they own moms and pops. {"index": 515, "sae_prompt": "According to a recent report, cheating among college and university students is on the rise. {"index": 516, "sae_prompt": "The following memo was published by the Welzaton City Commission.\n\"A recent nationwide study of the effectiveness of wearing a safety helmet while bicycling indicates that ten years ago approximately 35 percent of all bicyclists reported wearing helmets, whereas today that number is nearly 80 percent. Another study, however, cites a 200 percent increase in the number of serious accidents involving bicycles during the same period. Meanwhile, results of a local survey of frequent bicycle riders indicate that 75 percent of those riders feel 'much safer' on busy roads when they wear helmets than when they don't. Clearly, the best explanation for the rise in bicycle-related accidents is that bicyclists take more risks now than they did ten years ago because they feel safer when they are wearing helmets.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss one or more alternative explanations that could rival the proposed explanation and explain how your explanation(s) can plausibly account for the facts presented in the argument.", "aae_prompt": "Check it, the Welzaton City Commission done dropped this memo:\n\"Aight, so this study from all over the country been lookin' at how good it is to rock a safety helmet when you out here pedalin'. Like, ten years back 'bout 35 percent of folks on bikes was strappin' up with helmets, but now? We talkin' 'bout nearly 80 percent. But peep this, another study throwin' out there that we got a 200 percent jump in them bad wrecks with bikes in the same time frame. And then, you got this local poll where they hollered at people who ride a lot, and 75 percent of 'em say they feel way more chill on them crowded streets when they got their helmet on than when they rollin' without. So they sayin', for real, the reason we seein' more of them bike accidents is 'cause cats on bikes be takin' more chances nowadays since they feel all snug in their helmets.\"\n\nAight, so what you need to do is come up with some other reasons that might be why we seein' more of these bike mess-ups. You gotta break down how what you thinkin' could really be what's up, given all the stuff they laid out in that argument.", "esl_prompt": "The following memo was publish by the Welzaton City Commission.\n\"A recent nationwide study of the effectiveness of wearing a safety helmet while bicycling indicates that ten years ago approximately 35 percent of all bicyclist reported wearing helmets, whereas today that number is nearly 80 percent. Another study, however, cites a 200 percent increase in the number of serious accidents involving bicycles during the same period. Meanwhile, results of a local survey of frequent bicycle riders indicate that 75 percent of those riders feel 'much safer' on busy roads when they wear helmets than when they don't. Clearly, the best explanation for the rise in bicycle-related accidents is that bicyclists take more risks now than they did ten years ago because they feel safer when they are wearing helmets.\"\nWrite a response in which you discuss one or more alternative explanations that could rival the proposed explanation and explain how your explanation(s) can plausibly account for the facts presented in the argument.", "sae_essay": "One possible explanation for the rise in bicycle-related accidents is that bicyclists are riding more recklessly than they did ten years ago. This could be due to a sense of invincibility caused by the increased use of helmets, or it could be due to a feeling of anonymity on busy roads. Additionally, the availability of better bicycles and improved road conditions could be encouraging more people to take up bicycling, leading to more accidents.", "aae_essay": "The argument presented suggests that the increased use of safety helmets is the cause of the rise in bicycle accidents. This is a plausible argument, as helmets can provide a false sense of security and lead people to take more risks while riding their bikes. Additionally, the increased use of helmets may lead to more bicycle-related injuries due to a lack of protective gear for other parts of the body. Furthermore, the argument suggests that the increase in bicycle accidents is due to an increase in the number of people riding bicycles, which could be caused by a variety of factors such as improved infrastructure, increased public transportation options, or even a cultural shift towards more sustainable transportation.", "esl_essay": "One possible explanation for the rise in bicycle-related accidents is that bicyclists are riding more recklessly than they did ten years ago. This could be due to a sense of invincibility caused by the increased use of helmets, or it could be due to a feeling of anonymity on busy roads. Additionally, the availability of better bicycles and improved road conditions could be encouraging more people to take up bicycling, leading to more accidents."}
